catalyst.context: Highly oriented MoS 2 CdIn 2 S 4 (CISM) heterostructured photocatalyst is reported herein for efficient hydrogen evolution and CO 2 reduction applications.The catalyst is prepared by a simple hydrothermal method by varying MoS 2 (0, 0.5, 1 and 1.5 wt) and made a series of catalysts namely CIS, CISM0.5, CISM1 and CISM1.5, respectively for this study.The synthesized p-n heterojunction CISM1 photocatalyst showed efficient transfer of photoinduced carriers as well as close interfacial contact between MoS 2 and CdIn 2 S 4 in the hierarchical pseudo-spherical network.The catalyst CISM1 exhibits a hydrogen evolution rate of 2365 mol.g -1 h -1 which is two times higher than that of pristine CdIn 2 S 4 (1295 molg -1 h -1 ).Additionally, the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 to methanol has been explored.The conversation rate methanol formation is in the order of CISM1CISM1.5CISM0.5CISMoS 2 as 1276, 1066, 856, 544 and 253 mol.g -1 h -1 .cat,respectively.The photoelectrochemical study reveals that CISM1 exhibits 3 times higher in transition photocurrent (CISM1, 2.25 A/cm 2 ) compared to pristine material (CIS, 0.85 A/cm 2 ).The formation of heterojunction between MoS 2 and CdIn 2 S 4 furthermore, provides an exquisite mechanism for tuning the band potential for enhanced photocatalytic activity.Time-resolved photoluminescence decay spectra of CIS and CISM1 show a longer average lifetime of 3.3 ns and 4.1 ns, respectively.Notably, the photocatalyst shows excellent stability and potential application in renewable fuel generation.

catalyst.context: In a typical procedure, 0.4 mmol of Cadmium chloride, 0.2 mmol of Indium chloride tetrahydrate and 1 mmol of thioacetamide (TAA) were dissolved in distilled water (50 ml).The mixture was stirred for 30 min.The above solution is transferred into 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 160 C for 16 h 18.The synthesized material was collected and washed thoroughly with deionized water and ethanol and dried at 40 C temperature overnight. The desired heterostructure photocatalyst (1 wt of MoS 2 ) is synthesized typically by taking a fixed amount of synthesized CdIn 2 S 4 and dissolve it in 40 ml of deionized water in a round bottom flask.0.1 mmol of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate and 0.2 mmol of thioacetamide were added and stirred for 30 min to form a suspension.The above solution is transferred into 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and the mixture was heated at 210 C for 24 h 19.The final product was collected by centrifugation.The precipitate was washed thoroughly with deionized water and ethanol and dried overnight at 50 C temperature.The assynthesized samples MoS 2 CdIn 2 S 4 samples with 0.5 wt, 1 wt and 1.5 wt of MoS 2 are labeled as CISM0.5,CISM1 and CISM1.5, respectively.The synthesis process is illustrated in Fig. 1. The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction was carried out as in our previous paper 20.In a typical experiment, 20 mg of as-prepared catalyst was placed in 40 ml of aqueous solution in Pyrex photoreactor (125 ml) containing sacrificial electron donor (SED) and 300 W Xe arc lamp (visible light source) was positioned 10 cm far from the reactor to drive the photocatalytic reaction.The hydrogen production yield was examined by a gas chromatograph (Perkin Elmer Clarus 590 GC with Molecular Sieve/5 A column) operational with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD).The stability of the photocatalyst was tested for four successive cycles.On first cycle, photocatalytic activity was performed continuously for 4 h followed by degassing and purged with nitrogen gas before the second cycle of the experiment.Similarly, experiments were carried out in third and fourth cycles.The Apparent Quantum Efficiency (AQE) was evaluated for hydrogen production.The same procedure was followed by using different catalysts prepared in this study. The CO 2 reduction of photocatalysts was carried out in accordance with our recently reported work 21.In a typical reaction, an Xe arc lamp of 300 W is used as the light source to activate the photocatalytic reaction.The reactor is placed 10 cm far from the light source.The methanol yield was quantitatively determined by using Gas Chromatography FID using a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min, injector temperature: 250 o C, and FID detector temperature: 275 o C. catalyst.source: In summary, we reported a highly oriented pseudo-spherical MoS 2 CdIn 2 S 4 heterostructured catalyst via a facile hydrothermal method and employed both in H 2 production and CO 2 reduction study for the first time.
catalyst.context: In summary, we reported a highly oriented pseudo-spherical MoS 2 CdIn 2 S 4 heterostructured catalyst via a facile hydrothermal method and employed both in H 2 production and CO 2 reduction study for the first time.The unique band structure in CISM1 hybrid materials ensures a broad optical window for efficient light absorption and desired photo-redox chemical conversions.The humongous hydrogen production activity of CISM1 was unraveled by the construction of a pseudo-spherical network forming heterojunction between MoS 2 and CdIn 2 S 4 .It has further enabled the efficient transfer of photoinduced carriers as well as close interfacial contact between MoS 2 and CdIn 2 S 4 as clear-cut evidence from the HRTEM/HAADF study.CdIn 2 S 4 with the optimum MoS 2 content (1 wt) showed the highest value of hydrogen evolution rate of 2365 mol g -1 h -1 with AQE as 5.23.The photocatalyst was also studied for CO 2 reduction to methanol and showed the highest rate of conversion 1276 mol g -1 h -1 .The synthesized photocatalysts exhibited substantially improved visible light response, reduced electrical resistance and better separation of photoinduced charge carriers with a longer average lifetime.The durability of the photocatalytic system was tested for four consecutive runs without a significant decrease inactivity.Present work offers noble metal-free photocatalytic system consisting of photoactive chalcogenides for efficient solar to chemical energy conversion applications.
